articles.headline: Abortion Drives Ohio Election on Amending the State Constitution
articles.snippet: The election on Tuesday highlights how Republican legislators are using their power in Ohio and elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The election on Tuesday highlights how Republican legislators are using their power in Ohio and elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a century, Ohio voters have been able to amend the State Constitution with a simple majority vote.

articles.headline: Amazon to Meet Regulators as U.S. Considers Possible Antitrust Suit
articles.snippet: Amazon’s meetings with the Federal Trade Commission, known as “last rites” meetings, are typically a final step before the agency votes on filing a lawsuit.
articles.abstract: Amazon’s meetings with the Federal Trade Commission, known as “last rites” meetings, are typically a final step before the agency votes on filing a lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon is scheduled to meet with members of the Federal Trade Commission next week to discuss an antitrust lawsuit that the agency may be preparing to file to challenge the power of the retailer’s sprawling business, according to a person with knowledge of the plans.

articles.headline: Offshore Wind Runs Into Rising Costs and Delays
articles.snippet: Some troubled projects are raising concerns about the role to be played by offshore wind farms in tackling climate change.
articles.abstract: Some troubled projects are raising concerns about the role to be played by offshore wind farms in tackling climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vattenfall, a Swedish energy company, has for years been doing preliminary work for what would be one of the world’s largest offshore wind complexes, in the North Sea off eastern England.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: G.O.P. Contenders Feed Voter Distrust in Courts, Schools and Military
articles.snippet: As Donald J. Trump has escalated his attacks on the justice system and other core institutions, his competitors for the Republican nomination have followed his lead.
articles.abstract: As Donald J. Trump has escalated his attacks on the justice system and other core institutions, his competitors for the Republican nomination have followed his lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis says the military is more interested in global warming and “gender ideology” initiatives than in national security.

articles.headline: A Trucking Giant Is Bankrupt, and Finger-Pointing Begins
articles.snippet: Yellow, which was lent $700 million in U.S. pandemic relief, failed after being a laggard for years in a part of the industry where rivals are doing well.
articles.abstract: Yellow, which was lent $700 million in U.S. pandemic relief, failed after being a laggard for years in a part of the industry where rivals are doing well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yellow, one of the largest trucking companies in the United States, is now in bankruptcy, three years after it got a $700 million federal loan meant to help it weather the pandemic’s upheaval. So why are rivals of the 99-year-old freight hauler doing just fine?

articles.headline: Don’t Be So Picky About a Job, China’s College Graduates Are Told
articles.snippet: Under pressure from Beijing, Chinese schools have been told to do more to secure jobs for students, who are facing bleak prospects.
articles.abstract: Under pressure from Beijing, Chinese schools have been told to do more to secure jobs for students, who are facing bleak prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: At this year’s commencement ceremony for the Chongqing Metropolitan College of Science and Technology in southwestern China, the members of the graduating class did not receive the usual lofty message to pursue their dreams. Instead, they were dealt a harsh dose of reality.
articles.byline: By Claire Fu and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: What Cuisine Means to Taiwan’s Identity and Its Clash With China
articles.snippet: Chefs and restaurant owners are using a multiplicity of ingredients and tastes to reflect Taiwan’s roots, shaping a distinct culinary culture.
articles.abstract: Chefs and restaurant owners are using a multiplicity of ingredients and tastes to reflect Taiwan’s roots, shaping a distinct culinary culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taiwan is a self-ruling island of 24 million people that is officially known as the Republic of China. Only about a dozen countries recognize it as a nation because China claims it as one of its provinces. Taiwan is called “Chinese Taipei” by international organizations and at the Olympic Games.

articles.headline: Turbulent Waters: How the Black Sea Became a Hot Spot in the War
articles.snippet: The Black Sea, a largely overlooked part of the war in Ukraine, is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions. The region is deeply important to Moscow, Ukraine and the West.
articles.abstract: The Black Sea, a largely overlooked part of the war in Ukraine, is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions. The region is deeply important to Moscow, Ukraine and the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russian warships patrol the surface of the Black Sea, launching missiles at Ukrainian towns while creating a de facto blockade, threatening any vessel that might try to breach it.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: The Taliban Won but These Afghans Fought On
articles.snippet: But the Afghan resistance movement is no match for the Taliban’s military might.
articles.abstract: But the Afghan resistance movement is no match for the Taliban’s military might.
articles.lead_paragraph: One man spent his childhood in the foothills of northeastern Afghanistan dreaming of being a soldier for the U.S.-backed government. The other secretly applied to a military academy — against his parents’ wishes — determined to prove himself on the battlefield.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
